International Restrictions:
*All travellers: All travellers to Bermuda aged two years old and up need approved Travel Authorisation to enter the country. From 25 October, visitors arriving by air no longer require pre-travel tests or tests after arrival. Vaccinated visitors will be required to provide proof of vaccination as part of their application for travel authorisation. Unvaccinated visitors will be required to upload valid proof of travel health insurance to enter Bermuda. Travel Authorisation can be purchased for $40 up to a month before travel. To avoid being denied boarding, apply for your Travel Authorisation at least 24hrs before your day of departure. You can find more information on the COVID-19 Travel Authorisation on the Government of Bermuda’s website. Children 11 years and under travelling by air continue to have their Travel Authorisation Form assessed based on the vaccination status of their travelling guardian. Specific vaccine and testing requirements for travellers depends on mode of entry to Bermuda. You can find more information on travel requirements specific to you on the Government of Bermuda’s website. You must wear face masks when travelling to the departure airport and practice social distancing at the departure airport. Upon arrival, you must show a copy of your Travel Authorisation.
There are different entry requirements for returning residents and work permit holders. More information on travel requirements for residents and work permit holders can be found on the Government of Bermuda’s website. *If you’re fully vaccinated: To be considered fully vaccinated, at least 14 days must have passed since your second dose of the vaccine.
All vaccinated visitors to Bermuda aged 2 years and over are required to show proof of vaccination and have an approved Travel Authorisation to enter Bermuda. No on island testing, or quarantine is required after arrival.
Find out if you qualify as fully vaccinated in Bermuda on the Government of Bermuda’s website. Proof of vaccination status: Vaccinated visitors will be required to show proof of vaccination as part of their application for travel authorisation.
You cannot use the COVID Pass to demonstrate your vaccination record when entering Bermuda. You will need the Bermuda COVD-19 Travel Authorisation to prove your vaccination status. You can find more information on the COVID-19 Travel Authorisation on the Government of Bermuda’s website. *If you’re not fully vaccinated: From 22 August 2022, unvaccinated and not fully vaccinated visitors travelling by air will no longer be required to provide proof of medical exemption from COVID-19 vaccination.
All unvaccinated or not fully vaccinated visitors to Bermuda aged 2 years and over are required to have an approved Travel Authorisation to enter Bermuda. Proof of travel health insurance is also required for visitors who are unvaccinated or not fully vaccinated.
*Children and young people: Children 11 years and under travelling by air will have their Travel Authorisation Form assessed based on the vaccination status of their travelling guardian. You can find more information on the COVID-19 Travel Authorisation on the Government of Bermuda’s website. Children aged 2 - 11 years old do not need to be fully vaccinated but must still apply for the Bermuda COVID-19 Travel Authorisation. Children under 2 years do not need Travel Authorisation.
You can find more information on the requirements for children on the Government of Bermuda’s website.

Internal Restrictions:
*Accommodation: Resorts, hotels and cottages reopened at the beginning of July 2020. We recommend you check before you travel.
*Public spaces and services: Face masks are required to be worn indoors when travelling by bus, ferry (excluding the outdoor decks), taxi, limousine or minibus. Face masks are also required to be worn indoors when working in or visiting health service providers, prisons and at the airport.
Businesses may prefer to continue to require face masks be worn by people entering their premises or accessing their services. If so, all customers must comply with the mask policy of the business.
For further information on coronavirus regulations, you should consult the Bermuda Government website .
